FLAGG:
Not so much as It seems to excite the citizens of Albany.
Everywhere we go we hear talk of this railroad.
Topical, topical. Can't fight against it. Swim with the
current. Progress is what we're in for; but if it doesn't
interest you, forget, drop it, leave the whole thing. Men and
manners, that's your line; that's what you want to hear about:
manners and men; that's your interest. Well, you shall hear
about them; you shall read about them; you shall know about
them. Will you be here for the Fourth?
For the what?
Fourth of July.
Oh, the Day of Independence,
Independence Day; you must attend all the exercises, all the
ceremonies.
We are most anxious to do that; although we propose to leave
Albany on the evening of the Fourth.
Might we also attend a sitting of the legislature?
Not sitting; no, there's nothing doing in that line Just at
present.
Then where is the central government of the state being carried
on?
Central government? Central business? Isn't any; hardly^any;
not what you'd call central government. You can look around all
the bureaus; read all the ledgers, I don't care; but you won't
find much in the way of central government in this state. And
we're proud of it.
How are you proud of it? This seems very peculiar.
Initiative; leave things up to the people. The legislature only
deals with the whole state; everything else we leave to all the
